previous.name: Knowledge of the Faculties of Persons

segments.en: Numbered Discourses 6
6. The Great Chapter
63. Penetrative
“Mendicants, I will teach you a penetrative exposition of the teaching.

segments.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:
“Mendicants, what is the penetrative exposition of the teaching?

segments.pli: Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kāmānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kāmānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kāmanirodho veditabbo, kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (1)
segments.en: Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

segments.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, vedanānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, vedanānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, vedanānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, vedanānirodho veditabbo, vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (2)
segments.en: Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

segments.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, saññānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, saññānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, saññānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, saññānirodho veditabbo, saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (3)
segments.en: Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

segments.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, āsavānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, āsavānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, āsavānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, āsavanirodho veditabbo, āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (4)
segments.en: Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

segments.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, kammānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kammānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kammānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kammanirodho veditabbo, kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (5)
segments.en: Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.

segments.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā. (6)
segments.en: Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.

segments.pli: ‘Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā, kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavo veditabbo, kāmānaṃ vemattatā veditabbā, kāmānaṃ vipāko veditabbo, kāmanirodho veditabbo, kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’ That’s what I said,
but why did I say it?
There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
Sounds known by the ear …
Smells known by the nose …
Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: Api ca kho, bhikkhave, nete kāmā kāmaguṇā nāmete ariyassa vinaye vuccanti—
segments.en: However, these are not sensual pleasures. In the training of the noble one they’re called ‘kinds of sensual stimulation’.
Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.
Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,
but a wise one removes desire for them.
And what is the source of sensual pleasures?
Contact is their source.
And what is the diversity of sensual pleasures?

segments.pli: Añño, bhikkhave, kāmo rūpesu, añño kāmo saddesu, añño kāmo gandhesu, añño kāmo rasesu, añño kāmo phoṭṭhabbesu.
segments.en: The sensual desire for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches are all different.
This is called the diversity of sensual pleasures.
And what is the result of sensual pleasures?

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kāmayamāno tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ vipāko.
segments.en: When one who desires sensual pleasures creates a corresponding life-form, with the attributes of either good or bad deeds—this is called the result of sensual pleasures.
And what is the cessation of sensual pleasures?
When contact ceases, sensual pleasures cease.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of sensual pleasures is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

segments.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
segments.en: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ kāme pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kāmanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti kāmanirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands sensual pleasures in this way—and understands their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation—they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of sensual pleasures.

segments.pli: Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Sensual pleasures should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (1)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
There are these three feelings:

segments.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
segments.en: pleasant, painful, and neutral.
And what is the source of feelings?
Contact is their source.
And what is the diversity of feelings?

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, sāmisā sukhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā sukhā vedanā, atthi sāmisā dukkhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā dukkhā vedanā, atthi sāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā, atthi nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
segments.en: There are material pleasant feelings, spiritual pleasant feelings, material painful feelings, spiritual painful feelings, material neutral feelings, and spiritual neutral feelings.
This is called the diversity of feelings.
And what is the result of feelings?

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, vediyamāno tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā,
segments.en: When one who feels creates a corresponding life-form, with the attributes of either good or bad deeds—
this is called the result of feelings.
And what is the cessation of feelings?
When contact ceases, feelings cease.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ vedanaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti. So imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti vedanānirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands feelings in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of feelings.

segments.pli: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Feelings should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (2)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
There are these six perceptions:

segments.pli: rūpasaññā, saddasaññā, gandhasaññā, rasasaññā, phoṭṭhabbasaññā, dhammasaññā.
segments.en: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.
And what is the source of perceptions?
Contact is their source.
And what is the diversity of perceptions?

segments.pli: Aññā, bhikkhave, saññā rūpesu, aññā saññā saddesu, aññā saññā gandhesu, aññā saññā rasesu, aññā saññā phoṭṭhabbesu, aññā saññā dhammesu.
segments.en: The perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts are all different.
This is called the diversity of perceptions.
And what is the result of perceptions?
Communication is the result of perception, I say.

segments.pli: Yathā yathā naṃ sañjānāti tathā tathā voharati, evaṃ saññī ahosinti.
segments.en: You communicate something in whatever manner you perceive it, saying ‘That’s what I perceived.’
This is called the result of perceptions.
And what is the cessation of perception?
When contact ceases, perception ceases.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ saññaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saññānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti saññānirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands perception in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of perception.

segments.pli: Saññā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
segments.en: ‘Perceptions should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (3)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
There are these three defilements:
the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
And what is the source of defilements?
Ignorance is the source of defilements.
And what is the diversity of defilements?

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, āsavā nirayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā tiracchānayonigamanīyā, atthi āsavā pettivisayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā manussalokagamanīyā, atthi āsavā devalokagamanīyā.
segments.en: There are defilements that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.
This is called the diversity of defilements.
And what is the result of defilements?

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, avijjāgato tajjaṃ tajjaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṃ vā apuññabhāgiyaṃ vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, āsavānaṃ vipāko.
segments.en: When one who is ignorant creates a corresponding life-form, with the attributes of either good or bad deeds—this is called the result of defilements.
And what is the cessation of defilements?
When ignorance ceases, defilements cease.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of defilements is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ āsave pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ āsavānaṃ nirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti āsavanirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands defilements in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of defilements.

segments.pli: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā … pe … āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
segments.en: ‘Defilements should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (4)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ … pe … kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’ That’s what I said,
but why did I say it?
It is intention that I call deeds.
For after making a choice one acts
by way of body, speech, and mind.
And what is the source of deeds?
Contact is their source.
And what is the diversity of deeds?

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ nirayavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ tiracchānayonivedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ pettivisayavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ manussalokavedanīyaṃ, atthi kammaṃ devalokavedanīyaṃ.
segments.en: There are deeds that lead to rebirth in hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, the human world, and the world of the gods.
This is called the diversity of deeds.
And what is the result of deeds?
The result of deeds is threefold, I say:

segments.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme, upapajje vā, apare vā pariyāye.
segments.en: in this very life, on rebirth in the next life, or at some later time.
This is called the result of deeds.
And what is the cessation of deeds?
When contact ceases, deeds cease.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of deeds is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ kammaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammānaṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ kammanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti kammanirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands deeds in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of deeds.

segments.pli: Kammaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ … pe … kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
segments.en: ‘Deeds should be known. And their source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (5)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
segments.en: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: Iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
segments.en: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

segments.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, byādhipi dukkho, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ, saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
segments.en: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; illness is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
And what is the source of suffering?
Craving is the source of suffering.
And what is the diversity of suffering?

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ adhimattaṃ, atthi parittaṃ, atthi dandhavirāgi, atthi khippavirāgi.
segments.en: There is suffering that is severe, mild, slow to fade, and quick to fade.
This is called the diversity of suffering.
And what is the result of suffering?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco yena dukkhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati, yena vā pana dukkhena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhiṃ āpajjati:
segments.en: It’s when someone who is overcome and overwhelmed by suffering sorrows and pines and cries, beating their breast and falling into confusion. Or else, overcome by that suffering, they begin an external search, wondering:

segments.pli: ‘ko ekapadaṃ dvipadaṃ jānāti imassa dukkhassa nirodhāyā’ti?
segments.en: ‘Who knows one or two phrases to stop this suffering?’

segments.pli: Sammohavepakkaṃ vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ vadāmi pariyeṭṭhivepakkaṃ vā.
segments.en: The result of suffering is either confusion or a search, I say.
This is called the result of suffering.
And what is the cessation of suffering?
When craving ceases, suffering ceases.

segments.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhassa nirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segments.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ dukkhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa nidānasambhavaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa vemattataṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhassa vipākaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, so imaṃ nibbedhikaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pajānāti dukkhanirodhaṃ.
segments.en: When a noble disciple understands suffering in this way … they understand that this penetrative spiritual life is the cessation of suffering.

segments.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, veditabbaṃ, dukkhassa nidānasambhavo veditabbo, dukkhassa vemattatā veditabbā, dukkhassa vipāko veditabbo, dukkhanirodho veditabbo, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti.
segments.en: ‘Suffering should be known. And its source, diversity, result, cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation should be known.’

segments.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. (6)
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, bhikkhave, nibbedhikapariyāyo dhammapariyāyo”ti.
segments.en: This is the penetrative exposition of the teaching.”

suttaplex.blurb: A detailed analysis of several central themes, including sense perception, feeling, defilements, kamma, etc.
